The concept of illegal immigrants has its foundation in the Asian Exclusion Act of 1878. This was the result of the Kearney movement begun by Dennis Kearney, an Irish immigrant who was upset because the Chinese, after being laid off from building the railroads, were taking the lower paying jobs and physical labor. A 1913 California law barred Sikhs from owning land, even though the facts presented to the supreme Court showed they are Caucasians, the court ruled they were Asians. Today we exclude others form coming here who are willing to do these low paying hard labor jobs, in order to protect American labor. From the Capitalistic point of view, this is Socialism in action. For the neo-classical economists, Capitalism does not recognize borders. It calls for the free movement of labor and capital. Employers should be able to hire the best labor at the lowest rates, that is Capitalism. So when a Conservative rises in opposition to immigrant labor, and in particular, seasonal labor, just to satisfy some constituency, he/she is not practicing Capitalism, but is instead engaging in the hypocrisy of supporting Socialism.

It is also curious that those who claim to be the biggest champions of freedom and the right to revolt against oppressive governments, are willing to send the most vulnerable of these immigrants back to a life of poverty and subservience. While the Conservatives are lining up to support revolutions in Arabic countries, brought on by poverty, lack of employment and education, those who would risk everything just to come here and harvest lettuce, or melons, or oranges, are attacked as being criminals.

How can these Conservatives professing Christianity, find it in their nature to send young people who have never know another home, to a country where they do not speak the language, and even the culture is foreign to them. We frequently see very bright young people who are eligible to attend the best universities, sent away, or if the do graduate, denied the ability to apply that knowledge, all in the name of a contradictory demagoguery.

We see families who have made a home here, bought cars, houses, appliances, paid property taxes, and through the use of false Social Security numbers, paid into a system that they will not be able to collect from. And that kind of injustice is cheered on by the Conservatives. Even more hypocritical is the position of the Tea Party and Libertarians, who of all people should be for open borders for labor.

What is the difference between granting asylum to political refugees, while turning away economic refugees? By what moral code do you deliberately send hard working productive people back to unemployment and poverty? The founding fathers would be aghast at this practice. They made it plain that America was to be a place where others could come and make a new start in life. People risked everything to come here. They sailed in steerage under miserable conditions. They left their families and what few goods they had to come and do the hardest labor possible, and they did it willingly. Today we have that same spirit with these "Illegal Aliens," but they are not Europeans, they are Latin Americans, and they are being treated much as the Chinese, Sikhs, Filipinos, and other non Europeans were treated before them.

The invective, the outright hatred, the denigration of them and their culture is a continuation of those previous movements against them, and it is led by those whose motives are suspect.

I ask you: What do these right wing talking heads have to gain by creating this culture of hostility toward those who only want to escape oppressive governments and poverty? Who profits from denying these people the same liberties their ancestors came here for? Just what kind of moral cretins are these people. Look at them and see just what their values are.

Home ownership is not for everyone.  After a few years of owning and saving nothing while making the bank, local government, and various real estate agents rich, I sold for a small loss and am now happily renting and letting my landlord worry about those problems.  With two small kids, saving for college, retirement, putting food on the table, paying for the basics (food, garbage, power, phone, internet, tv) pretty much wipes out my paycheck.  Living in the bay area makes ownership ever harder (starter homes in the $500k's) so I think the whole idea of ownership is not for my generation.  It was good for my folks (their house cost less than $80k 30 years ago) but the math doesn't work out for me.  Now that the Republicans are talking about getting rid of Fannie and Freddie while increasing taxes and getting rid of interest deductions, the equation leans more towards renting.  So my question is then, if renting is going to be better than owning in the future, who will the owners be?  Perhaps the Chinese who own all our debt and have all our cash.  Think about that.

"American Exceptionalism" is the most distorted view anyone could hold of this country given its history of genocide and war mongering. If you believe in "American Exceptionalism" go talk to a Native American whose ancestors were slaughtered by the U.S. Cavalry or white settlers so that their land could be stolen right out from under them. Ask these Native Americans what they think of the U.S. Government forcing their ancestors to undertake long marches on which many died onto reservations located on barren land no one else wanted. Then, let's have a conversation with African-Americans whose ancestors were loaded onto slave ships against their will to be brought to the United States to be sold into slavery (that included, among other things, the sexual abuse of their children by white slave masters). If you believe the passage of time somehow rights these wrongs, you're exceptionally evil. No, fellow Americans, let's be truthful to ourselves and acknowledge that this country was built on such universal wrongs as genocide, murder, slavery and broken treaties with Native Americans. History shows that the U.S. Government never kept one treaty made with Native Americans. To tell you the truth, talk of "American Exceptionalism" makes me want to puke.

There is a sensible energy policy available that, had it been implemented 20 years ago, America would be in a far better place today. That said, there's not time like the present to start. Unfortunately, it's also political suicide to mention it, but here it goes: tax gasoline for all but aviation users at an additional 25 cents per gallon more per year (that is, 25 cents this year, 50 cents the next, 75 after that ...) every year from now until the end of time. Had this been started 20 years ago, the price of gas would be at most around $8.75 per gallon, which, while shocking to many, would be not too far from what many throughout the world are paying. What would be get from this tax? Well, we'd have smaller and more fuel efficient cars, without a doubt. We'd have houses built increasingly closer in, and the abandonment of insane 50+ mile single-car-occupant commutes. We'd have upwards of a trillion dollars in tax revenue for public transport and related infrastructure (or debt reduction). We'd have the respect of the world for taking a principled stand on global warming. We'd have no war in Iraq (or at least we would not be accused of duplicity in this), and we could act according to our principles in places like Saudi Arabia and Venezuela. We'd more quickly abandon the highly inefficient system of interstate trucking in favor of more intelligent multi-modal (read: train) approaches. The future of commercial aviation, the one user which actually does require high energy petroleum products, would be further secured. What would we have lost? Hummers would probably not have existed.

It's not too late to implement this now. I wonder what politician has the guts to even propose it?

This is taken from one (European) airlines web-site. (US airlines all have something similar). This is what you are agreeing to. Is it fraud to breach the terms of your contract? I'm not a lawyer, but your contract gives the airlines the right to the correct fare for your actual journey, or to not carry you in the future if you don't pay.

Note that the key component here is "Don't try and change your journey without our agreement".

3c1) Your ticket is valid only for the transportation shown on it from the place of departure through any agreed stopping places to the final place of destination. The fare you have paid is based on our tariff for the transportation shown on your ticket and forms part of your contract with us.

3c2) Your ticket is no longer valid if you do not use all the coupons in the sequence provided in the ticket. Where you change your travel without our agreement and the price for the resulting transportation you intend to undertake is greater than the price originally paid, you will be requested to pay the difference in price. Failure to pay the price applicable to your revised transportation will result in refusal of carriage.

3c3) If you want to change all or part of your transportation, you must contact us beforehand. We will work out the revised fare for your changed transportation. You will have the option of either accepting the revised fare or maintaining your original transportation.

3c4) If you need to change any aspect of your transportation because of events beyond your control, you must contact us as soon as possible. We will use reasonable efforts to transport you to your next stopover or final destination, without re-calculating the fare.

3c5) If you change your transportation without our agreement, your unused flight coupons will not be valid for travel and will have no value and we will not carry you until:

we or our authorised agents have re-calculated the revised fare for your actual transportation and
you have paid the difference (if any) between the fare you have already paid and the revised fare which applies to your changed transportation.
If the revised fare is lower than the fare you have already paid, we or our authorised agents will refund you the difference.

3c6) While some changes to your transportation will not result in a change of fare, others, such as changing the place of departure (for example, because you have not used the first flight coupon in your ticket or you have reversed the direction of your travel) may result in a fare increase. Many fares are valid only for travel on the dates and for the flights shown on the ticket. You may not be able to change these at all or only if you pay us an extra fee to do so.
